title: Welcome & Introduction
content: Kronos ORM (Kotlin Reactive Object-Relational-Mapping) is a modern Kotlin ORM framework based on KCP and designed for K2.

title: Welcome & Introduction
content: Kronos is a lightweight framework that provides developers with a simple solution for interacting with multiple databases.

title: Welcome & Introduction
content: Kronos analyzes IR expression trees to simplify code logic, making ORM coding concise and semantic. Through a compiler plugin, we also provide a simple solution for converting between Pojo and Map.

title: Welcome & Introduction
content: The design philosophy behind Kronos is to address the shortcomings of existing ORM frameworks and provide a more convenient and efficient data operation experience based on coroutines and task mechanisms.

title: Naming Strategy
content: KronosNamingStrategy is an interface used to define the conversion strategy for table and column names.

title: Naming Strategy
content: Convert database table/column names to kotlin class names/property names.

title: Naming Strategy
content: Convert kotlin class names/property names to database table/column names.

title: Common Strategy
content: KronosCommonStrategy is a common configuration strategy interface for update time/create time/logical deletion configuration strategies.

title: Common Strategy
content: Boolean type, indicating whether the strategy is enabled.

title: Common Strategy
content: Field type, indicating the corresponding field name.

title: Common Strategy
content: The field name attributes that need to be specified include name and columnName.

title: Locks in Kronos
content: Kronos provides a pessimistic lock (lock) function for query(select) and update insert(upsert) functions, and its lock level is row lock

title: Locks in Kronos
content: The lock() method can take no parameters or take a parameterlock, whose type is the enumeration class PessimisticLock

title: Locks in Kronos
content: Currently, you can choose exclusive lockPessimisticLock.X or shared lockPessimisticLock.S

title: Locks in Kronos
content: The following is only an example of using pessimistic lock when query(select). When using it when update insert(upsert), just replace .select() with .upsert()

title: Locks in Kronos
content: Kronos provides the optimistic lock function (for specific activation and usage methods, see: ï¼ˆOptimistic Lock Strategy)

title: Locks in Kronos
content: The column set to optimistic lock (default is version, which is used as an example below) will be set to 0 when the record is created, and version = version + 1 for each subsequent update

title: Locks in Kronos
content: When performing the update insert (upsert) operation, the version field will be added to the filter item, which means that the data will be updated only when the field in Kpojo is consistent with the number of modifications in the database, otherwise the insert will be executed

content:
graph LR
    A[Kronos] --> B[Kronos-core]
    B --> I[ORM for KPojo]
    I --> J[Queryã€Insertã€Updateã€Deleteï¼Œetc.]
    A --> C[Kronos-compiler-plugin]
    C --> L[Kronos-compiler-kotlin-plugin]
    C --> D[Kronos-maven-plugin]
    C --> E[Kronos-gradle-plugin]
    A --> F[Kronos-data-source-wrapper]
    F --> G[DataSource]
    G --> H[Mysql, Sqlite, Postgresql, Oracle, SqlServer, etc.]
    A --> K[Kronos-logging and Other Plugins]

title: Quick Start
content: You can use Kronos in your project by simply importing the kronos-core module and the kronos-compiler-plugin plugin.

title: Quick Start
content: At the same time, we provide a variety of optional dependencies such as logging (kronos-logging), database operation driver wrapper (kronos-jdbc-wrapper).

title: Quick Start
content: kronos-jdbc-wrapper is an optional module that provides a driver wrapper based on JDBC for the jvm platform. Of course, you can use other official driver wrappers or write your own wrapper class to easily use with third-party frameworks (such as SpringData, Mybatis, Hibernate, Jdbi, etc.) (refer to this article).

title: Quick Start
content: You can find some examples of how to start a project here.

title: Quick Start
content: Here, we will only discuss the usage of the kronos-jdbc-wrapper module with MySQL. The usage for other modules is similar. For specifics, please refer to Connecting to the Database.

title: Quick Start
content: Dependencies such as commons-dbcp2 and mysql-connector-java need to be included.

title: Quick Start
content: When using other databases or non-JVM platforms, the corresponding driver and configuration need to be used.

title: Reference Update
content: By configuring the column associations of KPojo with the [column association settings] directive and specifying the relationship information in @Reference with the usage property containing Update (or not specifying it, using the default), you can enable the cascading update feature for this class (or being) by specifying the associated fields.

title: Reference Update
content: In Kronos, we can use the cascade method to set whether to enable the cascade feature for the current update and limit the maximum cascade levels.

title: Reference Update
content: enabled: Boolean Manually set whether to enable the cascade feature for the current update (optional, defaults to true for enabling cascade).depth: Int Limits the maximum cascade levels, defaulting to -1, which means no limit on cascade levels. 0 indicates no cascade update.

title: Reference Update
section: and Related Methods for Cascade Updates
content: The methods and operations for cascading updates are similar to those for updating records.

title: Serialize Resolver
content: KronosSerializeResolver is a serialization resolver interface defined by Kronos, used for serialization and deserialization conversion between strings and Kotlin entity classes.

title: Serialize Resolver
content: Used to deserialize a string to the specified type T

title: Serialize Resolver
content: fun deserializeObj(serializedStr: String, kClass: KClass<*>): Any

title: Serialize Resolver
content: Used to deserialize a string to the specified KClass

title: Serialize Resolver
content: Used to serialize a Kotlin object to a String

title: Cascade Delete Action
content: Specify the operation when cascading deletion, see Cascading Delete for details.

title: Cascade Delete Action
content: Restrict deletion, if there is related data, deletion is not allowed

title: Cascade Delete Action
content: Set to the default value, the default value needs to specify the

title: Database Scheme Operation
content: Compared to kotoframework, Kronos is a Code-First ORM framework that adds operations on database table structures.

title: Database Scheme Operation
content: Related functions can be called through Kronos.dataSource(() -> KronosDataSourceWrapper) or a specific data source object (KronosDataSourceWrapper).

title: Database Scheme Operation
content: Use the exists method to check if the table exists, which returns a Boolean value.

title: Database Scheme Operation
content: Use the createTable method to create a table.

title: Database Scheme Operation
content: Use the dropTable method to delete a table.

title: Database Scheme Operation
content: Use the syncSchema method to synchronize the table structure.

title: Database Scheme Operation
content: The getTableCreateSqlList method is used to dynamically generate SQL statements for creating tables. The parameters received by getTableCreateSqlList include:

title: Database Scheme Operation
content: If you need to perform multiple database operations on the same entity object in succession, it is recommended not to use generics to avoid creating KPojo objects multiple times and incurring unnecessary overhead.

breadcrumbs: Driver for connection and Third-Party Framework
title: Driver for connection and Third-Party Framework
content: Kronos can be easily used with third-party frameworks by customizing the wrapper class that inherits the KronosDataSourceWrapper interface.

breadcrumbs: Driver for connection and Third-Party Framework
title: Driver for connection and Third-Party Framework
content: The following is an example using Springboot + Kronos + JDK 17 + Maven + Kotlin 2.0.0 to demonstrate how to use Kronos with the Spring framework.

breadcrumbs: Driver for connection and Third-Party Framework
title: Driver for connection and Third-Party Framework
content: It includes how to create a wrapper class based on spring-data-jdbc, so that there is no need to introduce additional dependencies such as kronos-jdbc-wrapper, and the database operation function can be realized only through kronos-core.

breadcrumbs: Driver for connection and Third-Party Framework
title: Driver for connection and Third-Party Framework

breadcrumbs: Driver for connection and Third-Party Framework
title: Driver for connection and Third-Party Framework
content: Introduce spring related dependencies and kronos-core dependencies ( see Quick Start for the introduction of compiler-plugin plug-in))

breadcrumbs: Driver for connection and Third-Party Framework
title: Driver for connection and Third-Party Framework
content: All code can be found in: SpringDataWrapper.kt

breadcrumbs: Driver for connection and Third-Party Framework
title: Driver for connection and Third-Party Framework
content: For frameworks that support named parameters, the syntax is almost the same as SpringDataWrapper.

breadcrumbs: Driver for connection and Third-Party Framework
title: Driver for connection and Third-Party Framework
content: For other frameworks that only support sequential parameters, you can get the parsed SQL statement through KAtomicQueryTask.parsed() or KAtomicActionyTask.parsed() or KronosAtomicBatchTask.parsedArr(), which contains the parameter name and parameter value array.

breadcrumbs: Driver for connection and Third-Party Framework
title: Driver for connection and Third-Party Framework
content: The subsequent process is the same as SpringDataWrapper, please refer to KronosBasicWrapper.kt.

title: Connect to DB
content: Kronos accesses the database through KronosDataSourceWrapper.

title: Connect to DB
content: KronosDataSourceWrapper is an interface that encapsulates database operations. It does not care about the specific database connection details and is independent of the platform. It only cares about the logic of database operations:

title: Connect to DB
content: dbType: database typeurl: database connection addressusername: database usernamequery: execute queryList

title: Connect to DB
content: : return the first column of the query resultsMap

title: Connect to DB
content: : return the first row of the query resultsT: return the first column of the first row of the query resultsexecute: execute updatebatch: batch updatetransaction: transaction

title: Connect to DB
content: KronosDataSourceWrapper is introduced in the core as an extension, which makes it possible to support multiple platforms, new database extensions and third-party framework integration.

title: Connect to DB
content: Officially provides a JDBC-based database connection plug-in for the jvm platform, which can be introduced in the following ways:

title: Connect to DB
content: In addition, you can use plugins such as kronos-spring-data-wrapper, kronos-jdbi-wrapper, kronos-mybatis-wrapper to connect to the database and integrate with Spring Data, JDBI, MyBatis and other frameworks.

title: Connect to DB
content: The following is an example of using kronos-jdbc-wrapper

title: Connect to DB
content: BasicDataSource is a simple data source implementation of Apache Commons DBCP. You can replace it with other data source implementations.

title: Kotlin Type to KColumnType
content: The mapping relationship between common Kotlin types and Kronos column types is as follows: When the ColumnType annotation is not used, Kronos will automatically infer the database column type based on the Kotlin type. You can refer to the following table to view the mapping relationship between Kotlin data types and Kronos column types (KColumnType). The performance of Kronos column types varies in different databases. For details, please refer to Kronos column types.

title: Index Methods and Index Types
content: Binary tree index is the most common index type. No need to specify it, MySQL uses this index by default.

title: Index Methods and Index Types
content: Hash indexes are only supported by the Memory engine and do not support range queries.

title: Index Methods and Index Types
content: Ordinary index, no need to specify, MySQL uses this index by default.

title: Index Methods and Index Types
content: Unique index, used to ensure data uniqueness.

title: Index Methods and Index Types
content: Full-text indexing is supported only by the MyISAM engine and is used for full-text search.

title: Index Methods and Index Types
content: Spatial index, used for spatial data types, supports range queries.

title: Index Methods and Index Types
content: Binary tree index, no need to specify, PostgreSQL uses this index by default.

title: Index Methods and Index Types
content: Hash index is used for equality query and does not support range query.

title: Index Methods and Index Types
content: General index, supports range query, and supports spatial index.

title: Index Methods and Index Types
content: General inverted index for full-text search.

title: Index Methods and Index Types
content: Range index, used for large tables.

title: Index Methods and Index Types
content: Unique index, used to ensure data uniqueness.

title: Index Methods and Index Types
content: Ordinary index, no need to specify, Oracle uses this index by default.

title: Index Methods and Index Types
content: Bitmap index, used for high-concurrency queries and suitable for low-cardinality columns.

title: Index Methods and Index Types
content: Unique index, used to ensure data uniqueness.

title: Index Methods and Index Types
content: Unique index, used to ensure data uniqueness.

title: Index Methods and Index Types
content: Clustered index, the physical order of the data in the table is consistent with the logical order of the index.

title: Index Methods and Index Types
content: For non-clustered indexes, the physical order of the data in the table is inconsistent with the logical order of the index.

title: Index Methods and Index Types
content: XML index, for XML data type.

title: Index Methods and Index Types
content: Spatial index, used for spatial data types.

title: Index Methods and Index Types
content: Unique index, used to ensure data uniqueness.

title: Select Records
content: In Kronos, we can use the KPojo.select() method to query records in the database.

title: Select Records
content: The select method is used to specify the query field. At this time, Kronos will generate a query field statement based on the field set by the select method.

title: Select Records
content: You can pass in a string as the query field, use + to connect multiple fields, and the as method is used to set the field alias.

title: Select Records
section: Generate conditional statements and query records based on KPojo object values
content: When the by or where method is not used, Kronos will generate query conditional statements based on the values of the KPojo object.

title: Select Records
section: Generate conditional statements and query records based on KPojo object values
content: null values will not be included in the query conditions, that is, null values will not be used to generate query conditional statements. If you need to query null values, please use the where method to set the query conditions.

title: Select Records
content: The by method is used to set query conditions. At this time, Kronos will generate query condition statements based on the fields set by the by method.

title: Select Records
content: The where method is used to set query conditions. At this time, Kronos will generate query condition statements based on the fields set by the where method.

title: Select Records
section: to add parameters to custom query conditions
content: When the where condition contains custom SQL such as: where { "id = :id".asSql() }, you can use the patch method to add parameters to the custom query condition.

title: Select Records
content: The orderBy method is used to set sorting conditions. At this time, Kronos will generate sorting condition statements based on the fields set by the orderBy method.

title: Select Records
content: Use the asc method to set ascending sorting, and use the desc method to set descending sorting.

title: Select Records
content: When the sorting method is not set, the default is ascending sorting, such as: orderBy { it.id }.

title: Select Records
section: to set grouping and aggregation conditions
content: The groupBy method is used to set grouping conditions, and the having method is used to set aggregation conditions.

title: Select Records
section: to set the number of query records
content: The limit method is used to set the number of query records. At this time, Kronos will generate query condition statements based on the number of records set by the limit method.

title: Select Records
section: to set a row lock during query
content: The lock method is used to set a row lock during query. At this time, Kronos will add a lock according to the lock type set by the lock method.

title: Select Records
content: The page method is used to set up paging query. Please note that the parameters of the page method start from 1.

title: Select Records
content: The syntax of paging query is different in different databases. Kronos will generate corresponding paging query statements based on different databases.

title: Select Records
content: After using the page method, the query result will not include the total number of records by default. If you need to query the total number of records, please use the withTotal method.

title: Select Records
section: to set the query database (cross-database query)
content: The db method is used for cross-database query. In this case, Kronos will set the query database according to the parameters of the db method.

title: Select Records
section: method to query a single record
content: The single method is actually an abbreviation of limit(1) and is used to query a single record.

title: Select Records
section: method to query the Map list
content: The query method is used to execute a query and return a Map list.

title: Select Records
section: Use queryList to query a list of a specified type
content: The queryList method is used to execute a query and return a list of a specified type. It can accept generic parameters.

title: Select Records
section: Use queryList to query a list of a specified type
content: When querying a single column, you can directly set the generic parameter to the type of the column, for example: queryList().

title: Select Records
section: Use queryList to query a list of a specified type
content: When querying multiple columns, you can set the generic parameter to a subclass of KPojo, for example: queryList().

title: Select Records
section: Use queryList to query a list of a specified type
content: When no generic parameter is set, Kronos automatically converts the query result to the KPojo type of the query.

title: Select Records
section: Use queryList to query a list of a specified type
content: queryList uses KCP to convert Map to KPojo. For details, see: Conversion between KPojo and Map

title: Select Records
content: The queryMap method is used to execute a query and return a Map. When the query result is empty, null is returned.

title: Select Records
section: Use queryOne to query a single record
content: The queryOne method is used to execute a query and return a single record. When the query result is empty, an exception is thrown. Generic parameters can be accepted.

title: Select Records
section: Use queryOne to query a single record
content: When querying a single column, the generic parameter can be directly set to the column type, for example: queryOne()`.

title: Select Records
section: Use queryOne to query a single record
content: When querying multiple columns, the generic parameter can be set to a subclass of KPojo, for example: queryOne()`.

title: Select Records
section: Use queryOne to query a single record
content: When the generic parameter is not set, Kronos automatically converts the query result to the KPojo type of the query.

title: Select Records
section: Use queryOne to query a single record
content: queryOne uses KCP to convert Map to KPojo. For details, see: KPojo and Map conversion

title: Select Records
section: Use queryOneOrNull to query a single record (optional)
content: Similar to the queryOne method, the queryOneOrNull method is used to execute a query and return a single record. When the query result is empty, it returns null and can accept generic parameters.

title: Select Records
section: Use queryOneOrNull to query a single record (optional)
content: When querying a single column, you can directly set the generic parameter to the column type, for example: queryOneOrNull()`.

title: Select Records
section: Use queryOneOrNull to query a single record (optional)
content: When querying multiple columns, you can set the generic parameter to a subclass of KPojo, for example: queryOneOrNull()`.

title: Select Records
section: Use queryOneOrNull to query a single record (optional)
content: When the generic parameter is not set, Kronos automatically converts the query result to the KPojo type of the query.

title: Select Records
section: Use queryOneOrNull to query a single record (optional)
content: queryOneOrNull uses KCP to implement Map conversion to KPojo. For details, see: KPojo and Map conversion

title: Select Records
section: to query a paginated query with a total number of records
content: The withTotal method is used to query a paginated query with a total number of records. In this case, Kronos will include the total number of records in the query results.

title: Select Records
section: to query a paginated query with a total number of records
content: The withTotal method returns a PageClause object, and you can use the query, queryList and other methods to get the query results.

title: Select Records
content: In Kronos, we can use a specified data source to query records in the database.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: Declaring a data class as a table class in Kronos is very simple. You just need to make the class inherit from KPojo. Here is a simple example:

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: For more complex data classes and when working with database table operations, here are examples of table creation statements in different databases:

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: We define the properties of the data table through annotations and configuration options, such as primary keys, auto-increment, unique keys, and indexes.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: Why use annotations instead of Kotlin DSL?

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: We read annotation information through a compiler plugin and store the information in the entity class definition, so that all table structure parsing occurs at compile time rather than runtime. While this approach sacrifices some flexibility, it helps avoid runtime performance overhead.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: You can create a custom table naming strategy by implementing a class that extends KronosNamingStrategy (see: Naming Strategy), and then specify this implementation in the configuration file.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: We provide a default LineHumpNamingStrategy for table naming:

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: This strategy converts Kotlin class names to lowercase strings separated by underscores, e.g., ADataClass -> a_data_class, and converts database table/column names to camel case, e.g., user_name -> userName.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: Similar to the table naming strategy, you can create a custom field naming strategy by implementing a class that extends KronosNamingStrategy, and then specify this implementation in the configuration file.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: We also provide the LineHumpNamingStrategy as the default field naming strategy.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: You can customize the create time strategy by creating a class that implements KronosCommonStrategy (see: Common Strategy), and then specify this implementation in the configuration file.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: The create time strategy is globally disabled by default and needs to be manually enabled.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: Even after setting the global create time strategy, you can still override it in a KPojo class using the @CreateTime annotation.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: Similar to the create time strategy, you can customize the update time strategy by creating a class that implements KronosCommonStrategy, and then specify this implementation in the configuration file.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: The update time strategy is globally disabled by default and needs to be manually enabled.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: Even after setting the global update time strategy, you can still override it in a KPojo class using the @UpdateTime annotation.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: You can customize the logic delete strategy by creating a class that implements KronosCommonStrategy, and then specify this implementation in the configuration file.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: The logic delete strategy is globally disabled by default and needs to be manually enabled.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: Even after setting the global logic delete strategy, you can still override it in a KPojo class using the @LogicDelete annotation.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: You can customize the optimistic lock strategy by creating a class that implements KronosCommonStrategy, and then specify this implementation in the configuration file.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: You can also configure each entity object individually using Column Optimistic Lock.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: The optimistic lock strategy is globally disabled by default and needs to be manually enabled.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: Even after setting the global optimistic lock strategy, you can still override it in a KPojo class using the @Version annotation.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: Kronos uses the yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss format by default for dates/times. You can modify the default format as follows:

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: Kronos uses the current system timezone by default. You can modify the default timezone as follows:

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: You can create a custom serialization resolver by implementing a class that extends KronosSerializeResolver, and then specify this implementation in the configuration file.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: For example, you can use the GSON library to implement a serialization resolver:

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: In this example, we use the GSON library to implement a serialization resolver. You can use any library such as Kotlinx.serialization, Jackson, Moshi, FastJson, etc.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: Specifies the table name for a data table. If not specified, the default table naming strategy will be used.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: Specifies an index for the data table. If not specified, no index will be created.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: : Index column namestype String: Index type (optional)method String: Index method (optional)

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: Used to specify whether the data table enables the creation time strategy. If not specified, the global setting will be used.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: Used to specify whether the data table enables the update time strategy. If not specified, the global setting will be used.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: Used to specify whether the data table enables the logical deletion strategy. If not specified, the global setting will be used.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: Used to specify the column name of the data table. If not specified, the default column name strategy will be used.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: Used to specify the date/time format of the data table. If not specified, the default date/time format will be used.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: Used to declare whether the column needs to be deserialized. If not specified, deserialization will be disabled by default. If enabled, the Kronos.serializeResolver.deserialize method will be called to deserialize the value of the column into the specified type.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: @Reference(reference: String[], target: String[], onDelete: CascadeDeleteAction, defaultValue: String, mapperBy: String)

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: This annotation is used to declare column associations, including association queries, association inserts, association updates, association deletions, etc. It supports one-to-one, one-to-many, many-to-one, and many-to-many associations.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: Kronos treats associated columns as custom properties and does not recognize them as database fields.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: The association feature in Kronos does not require defining foreign keys. Only defining the association relationship in the entity class is needed to achieve association queries, association inserts, association updates, association deletions, etc.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: : Associated target table property namesonDelete CascadeDeleteAction: Associated deletion strategy (optional, default is no action)defaultValue Array

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: : Default values to be set when the cascade delete action is "SET DEFAULT" (optional)mapperBy Array

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: : Used to specify the maintenance end of this association relationship (empty means the maintenance end is the current entity; it cannot be empty when both ends have this annotation)usage Array

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: : Used to declare the association operations needed for this entity (optional, default is [Insert, Update, Delete, Upsert, Select])

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: This annotation is used to declare a column as the primary key.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: identity Boolean: Whether it is auto-incremented

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: For different database types, Kronos will automatically convert the Kotlin types based on the Kotlin type's mapping to the database types. You can refer to Kotlin Type to KColumn Type for the mapping relationship between Kotlin data types and database types. You can use this annotation to declare the column type and length. If not specified, the default type and length will be used. Please refer to Kronos Column Types for all type information.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: This annotation is used to declare a column as not null. If not specified, the default not null constraint will be used.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: This annotation is used to declare a column as the creation time field. If not specified, the default creation time strategy will be used.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: enabled Boolean: Whether it is enabled

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: This annotation is used to declare a column as the update time field. If not specified, the default update time strategy will be used.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: enabled Boolean: Whether it is enabled

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: This annotation is used to declare a column as the logical deletion field. If not specified, the default logical deletion strategy will be used.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: enabled Boolean: Whether it is enabled

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: This annotation is used to declare a column as the optimistic lock field. If not specified, the default optimistic lock strategy will be used.

title: Table Class Definition and Configuration
content: enabled Boolean: Whether it is enabled
